HOME.PART_1: While testing a new version of Angular, I decided to create this website to detail and summarize the most relevant things I have been programming up to now. Once it is finished, I will upload it here on my GitHub Pages.
HOME.PART_2:
• Personal Section: I show personal projects that I find interesting.
  • Work Section: I mention some technical tasks of work projects in which I participated.

PRJA.PART_1: First work project. Banking project migrated from Visual Basic.
PRJA.PART_2: Some tasks were: Develop forms with validations and nested fields. Generate reports in Excel format.
PRJA.PART_3: Build Java tests using JUnit.
PRJA.PART_4: {[java]} (Backend. Eclipse IDE. Spring Framework. Oracle Database. Hibernate. Maven. Apache Tomcat)

PRJB.PART_1: User management project. It included a website and a mobile application.
PRJB.PART_3: Create a barcode and QR code scanner, to do this I used the WebRTC API with the help of the ZXing library.
PRJB.PART_4: Convert pages with user information into an image for downloading or sharing.
PRJB.PART_5: {[ionic]} (Hybrid mobile application. Angular. TypeScript. Cordova. Android. iOS)

PRJC.PART_1: This project was a website to register events.
PRJC.PART_2: Its main page worked as a timeline of events, in which it was possible to filter, expand or create new ones.
PRJC.PART_3: Some tasks were: Implement functionality to insert and modify events,
PRJC.PART_4: with the possibility of inserting rich text, attachments, images from camera, voice recordings, current location.
PRJC.PART_5: Perform actions in an offline mode and synchronize everything when reconnecting. Build a notification system.
PRJC.PART_6: {[csharp]} (Backend. Visual Studio. .NET Framework. MSSQL. SignalR. Entity Framework. LINQ. NuGet)

PRJD.PART_1: This project was a web tool that worked to coordinate different actions of a company.
PRJD.PART_2: Some tasks were: Dynamic uploading of documents based on data from multiple forms.
PRJD.PART_3: Generate a connection layer with SharePoint to share files on the network.
PRJD.PART_4: Configure features to work correctly in Internet Explorer 9.
PRJD.PART_5: {[java]} (Backend. Eclipse IDE. Servlets. JDBC. Oracle Database)

PRJE.PART_1: Project focused on developing a website designed to function as Home Banking.
PRJE.PART_2: Some tasks were: Implement the Microfrontend architecture to split application modules into separate projects.
PRJE.PART_3: Modify a view to display data in a pie or circle chart.
PRJE.PART_6: {[react]} (Used in some project modules. TypeScript. Highcharts)

PRJF.PART_1: This project was a CRM-type website focused on debt management.
PRJF.PART_2: Some tasks were: Develop a tool that allows reading any Excel file, extracting the desired information,
PRJF.PART_3: and downloading it into a new file with a predefined template. Modify file import services to process the information and save it in the database.

GUITARWEBGAME.PART_1: Practice project. This started as an experiment to build a process that would read the notes indicated in a MIDI sequence file.
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_2: In this process each note is read in its own time and will be displayed on the screen.
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_3: Based on this I decided to create a web rhythm game with a Guitar Hero style.
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_4: I had the idea that the songs should be from live concerts and you can watch their videos while playing,
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_5: for this I used the YouTube IFrame API.
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_7: {[npm]} → express (Package used to start a server that hosts the game website. It also provides services to get the songlist or get information about the selected song)
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_8: {[npm]} → @tonejs/midi (Package used to read the midi file that contains the notes)
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_9: {[npm]} → ini (Package used to read the ini file that contains the song information)
GUITARWEBGAME.PART_10: {[js]} (Frontend. Vanilla. Notes processing is done in a loop within the WebAPI requestAnimationFrame function)

DOSWAR.PART_1: Project started with the goal of making my own online multiplayer game.
DOSWAR.PART_2: It's a Counter Strike 2D style game created with the Unity engine.
DOSWAR.PART_3: I focused on the technical side, that's why I used 2D graphics with a simple design inspired by the DOS systems.
DOSWAR.PART_4: It's playable in LAN and over Internet. Team based and has different weapons to choose from.
DOSWAR.PART_5: Respawns are infinite, but my idea was to do it in rounds.
DOSWAR.PART_6: The maps and the editor currently have only one object.
DOSWAR.PART_7: {[unity]} (Game engine. Package UNet for networking and objects synchronization)
DOSWAR.PART_8: {[csharp]} (General functionality and game systems. Additionally I added Rich Presence on Discord and IP encryption with AES)
DOSWAR.PART_9: {[php]} (Used for the match list. It works through a PHP file hosted on a server. I built it to provide two services, one allows to get the list, and the other one allows to add a new match)

ALUNDRE.PART_1: This project is the second game I was able to complete with Unity. I started it to test the Tilemaps tool that comes with this engine.
ALUNDRE.PART_2: To do that, I downloaded some Assets of the PlayStation game Alundra, which included several files to experiment with.
ALUNDRE.PART_3: After getting the basic stuff working, I decided to move the project forward and create my own version of this game.
ALUNDRE.PART_4: The Sprites and sounds are taken from the original game. The game mechanics and the game stage were built from scratch.
ALUNDRE.PART_5: I planned an ambitious map and that was what took me the most time. The most challenging part was to develop the behavior of the enemies.

PORTABLE.PART_1: I made this program to generate a single portable and self-extracting executable.
PORTABLE.PART_2: Example of how it works with one of my games:
PORTABLE.PART_3: A compressed ZIP file is linked at compile time, in this case it contains all the necessary game files.
PORTABLE.PART_4: When it runs, it first checks whether the extraction folder exists and if it contains any files.
PORTABLE.PART_5: If the folder already exists, the process opens the specified file and stops. If the folder does not exist, the process creates it and continues.
PORTABLE.PART_6: Reads the linked ZIP and extracts its contents.
PORTABLE.PART_7: After extracting all, it opens the specified file, in this case, the executable of the game.
PORTABLE.PART_8: {[c]} (Libraries zlib and minizip to handle ZIP files. Compiler gcc)
PORTABLE.PART_9: {[cpp]} (Main code. Compiler g++. Utility windres to generate the resource file)

CONTROL.PART_1: Simple remote control that allows to send commands to the VLC media player from another device.
CONTROL.PART_2: The goal is to be able to control the application from the phone without the need to use the PC.
CONTROL.PART_3: It works through a web site that is accessible from the local network.
CONTROL.PART_4: Features: previous and next buttons, volume buttons, mute button,
CONTROL.PART_5: button to select from the current playlist, button to close the application and shutdown Windows.
CONTROL.PART_7: {[npm]} → express (Package used to start a server that hosts the website)
CONTROL.PART_8: {[npm]} → socket.io (Package used to communicate client and server)

RANDOMBOT.PART_1: This is a Discord Bot created for entertainment and to experiment with its capabilities.
RANDOMBOT.PART_2: The data is obtained from various web pages and then sent to the text or voice channel.
RANDOMBOT.PART_3: Some commands allow you to: get random words, fetch random emojis from Twitch,
RANDOMBOT.PART_4: discover random metal bands, get random sounds, generate text-to-speech, listen to a radio.
RANDOMBOT.PART_6: {[npm]} → discord.js (Package used to interact with the Discord API)
RANDOMBOT.PART_7: {[js]} (jQuery to facilitate data extraction and element manipulation)
